chapter.title: Welcome to this LINCS course
chapter.content:
Introduction

Welcome to the Legal Issues, Self-Disclosure, and Confidentiality online course of the Learning to Achieve Training Program, a research-based training on serving adults with learning disabilities.

This program is brought to you by the Literacy Information and Communication System (LINCS).

This course was developed under the LINCS Regional Professional Development Center for Adult Education, PR/Award Number V191B110003, administered by the Office of Career, Technical, and Adult Education, U. S. Department of Education. chapter.title: Join the LINCS Community and participate in course discussions
chapter.content:
Join the LINCS Community and participate in course discussions

This online course is designed for teachers of adult learners with learning disabilities (LD). As with all LINCS courses, this course includes opportunities to connect with other adult education practitioners interested in the field of LD. If you haven’t already done so, take a moment to register as a member of the LINCS Community and participate in the discussions related to this course. The discussions provide an open forum to share your thoughts, ideas, and questions with other adult education practitioners.

Throughout this course, you will have the opportunity to share your stories and insights as you learn ways to support your students with LD in self-disclosing their disability appropriately, while ensuring your program’s compliance with federal laws. This is a great opportunity to share and learn from others. We encourage you to participate.

chapter.title: Course objectives
chapter.content:
Course objectives

In this Course, we will examine legal and ethical issues that specifically affect adults with learning disabilities (LD). We are not offering you this information so you can provide legal advice to individuals with LD you work with, but rather so you have an understanding of the law to guide your professional practice.

Upon completion of this course, you will be able to:

  • identify the legal, self-disclosure and confidentiality issues that are relevant to service providers working with adults with LD; and
  • discuss possible implications for service delivery when a student discloses a learning disability.

Please allow approximately 1 hour to complete this course. However, you are free to leave the session at any time. When you exit the courseware, a bookmark is automatically placed at your last location to allow you to pick up where you left off when you return.

chapter.title: Guiding questions
chapter.content:
Guiding questions

To help guide our learning, we will refer to three guiding questions:

  1. Which federal laws affect adults with LD?
  2. What does choosing to disclose or not to disclose mean to adults with LD?
  3. How can information about LD be kept confidential?

It is important for adults with LD to be aware of existing federal laws in order to understand their rights as individuals with disabilities and how to advocate for those rights in both school and work environments. The relevant laws change as individuals with LD leave secondary school and become adults. Adults with LD must understand these laws in order to exercise their rights and ask for accommodations. We’ll talk about each of these guiding questions one at a time.
